text: When i think about the salary question, I wonder if mentioning that i would accept a lower salary would be beneficial. Yes it would make the company lowball me and undervalue me, but with how competitive the industry is at the moment, I wonder if this is a reasonable take in order to get job experience or a stable job in a somewhat timely manner. I think the answer would be to never mention that you are okay with a lower salary because it means you will almost certainly lose money, but with the competitive market, it might be viable?

elements.text: When i think about the salary question, I wonder if mentioning that i would accept a lower salary would be beneficial. Yes it would make the company lowball me and undervalue me, but with how competitive the industry is at the moment, I wonder if this is a reasonable take in order to get job experience or a stable job in a somewhat timely manner. I think the answer would be to never mention that you are okay with a lower salary because it means you will almost certainly lose money, but with the competitive market, it might be viable?

text: HR here :slightly_smiling_face: One option to consider would be asking for the salary range for the position before providing a specific number. Most of the time, they will share the budget with you and you can let them know whether or not you are comfortable with that.

elements.text: HR here

One option to consider would be asking for the salary range for the position before providing a specific number. Most of the time, they will share the budget with you and you can let them know whether or not you are comfortable with that.

text:
I would let them set the range, then negotiate where you want to be in that range.

Pass the "what you would like to make" question back to them with a statement that you're more concerned that you'll be a good fit for each other, first.

elements.text:
I would let them set the range, then negotiate where you want to be in that range.

Pass the "what you would like to make" question back to them with a statement that you're more concerned that you'll be a good fit for each other, first.

text: Also, do your own market research on the salary range for the position in your area. It gives you some negotiating power knowing that beforehand

elements.text: Also, do your own market research on the salary range for the position in your area. It gives you some negotiating power knowing that beforehand

text: It is also becoming much more common for companies to list a range in job descriptions especially when recruiting nationally because certain states require it now. That doesn't mean every position will have it but I'm seeing it more and more.

elements.text: It is also becoming much more common for companies to list a range in job descriptions especially when recruiting nationally because certain states require it now. That doesn't mean every position will have it but I'm seeing it more and more.

text: A technique I discovered recently to help calm me down is to take a deep breath, inhale once more, and then exhale. Calms you down and personally provides the benefit of having something to focus on that isn't the current stressor.

elements.text: A technique I discovered recently to help calm me down is to take a deep breath, inhale once more, and then exhale. Calms you down and personally provides the benefit of having something to focus on that isn't the current stressor.

text: definitely practice your answers to questions, because your brain can sometimes psych out during stress. Before a piano recital, its common for you to forget parts of a song or think you are not ready. to practice before to the point where you somewhat memorize a response will help you dramatically

elements.text: definitely practice your answers to questions, because your brain can sometimes psych out during stress. Before a piano recital, its common for you to forget parts of a song or think you are not ready. to practice before to the point where you somewhat memorize a response will help you dramatically

text: What are some ways to limit saying 'um' or 'like' as a filler word in interviews? I had an interview today and realized I was saying 'um' a lot and once I became aware of it, I kept forgetting what I was talking about.

elements.text: What are some ways to limit saying 'um' or 'like' as a filler word in interviews? I had an interview today and realized I was saying 'um' a lot and once I became aware of it, I kept forgetting what I was talking about.

text: Practice, practice, practice.

elements.text: Practice, practice, practice.

text: another thing is to make notes of answers, not word for word, but just a bullet points of topics you want to touch. that helped me a lot during speech, when i stopped writing my speeches, and then started writing the topics i wanted to cover, and then just improvised around those topics

elements.text: another thing is to make notes of answers, not word for word, but just a bullet points of topics you want to touch. that helped me a lot during speech, when i stopped writing my speeches, and then started writing the topics i wanted to cover, and then just improvised around those topics

text: Set up a call or some texts with a friend and ask them to tell you nice things about yourself, might also help with your About Me

elements.text: Set up a call or some texts with a friend and ask them to tell you nice things about yourself, might also help with your About Me

text: I'm guilty of that a lot too. Take a beat before you answer and think about the specific words you want to say. Being slow and deliberate to answer is rarely a bad thing

elements.text: I'm guilty of that a lot too. Take a beat before you answer and think about the specific words you want to say. Being slow and deliberate to answer is rarely a bad thing

text: Yeah, this is something I struggle with as well. Trying to condition myself to pause before I move to the next thought.

elements.text: Yeah, this is something I struggle with as well. Trying to condition myself to pause before I move to the next thought.

text: Practice speaking slower, it will help you watch what you say more closely, and pauses. Also we did ToastMasters in our last job which was fun and insightful.

elements.text: Practice speaking slower, it will help you watch what you say more closely, and pauses. Also we did ToastMasters in our last job which was fun and insightful.

text: definitely make a cognative note on when you do it, and try to practice not saying anything at all and just waiting to finish your thoughts. The interviewer will understand and appreciate you taking the time to form out your thoughts and think about the questions before answering

elements.text: definitely make a cognative note on when you do it, and try to practice not saying anything at all and just waiting to finish your thoughts. The interviewer will understand and appreciate you taking the time to form out your thoughts and think about the questions before answering

text:
Not exactly a destresser, but I also find it helpful to jot down a couple of keywords from the question they ask in the moment so I can reference it if I feel I am starting to get off track.

It helps me take a moment to make sure I'm actually answering the question / helps me feel more confident and less nervous in the moment.

elements.text:
Not exactly a destresser, but I also find it helpful to jot down a couple of keywords from the question they ask in the moment so I can reference it if I feel I am starting to get off track.

It helps me take a moment to make sure I'm actually answering the question / helps me feel more confident and less nervous in the moment.

text: Yes, recording yourself is a great way to get feedback, especially over time. I use that for violin practice so I can see the improvement over time.

elements.text: Yes, recording yourself is a great way to get feedback, especially over time. I use that for violin practice so I can see the improvement over time.

text: also dont be afraid to tell them "oh thats a good question! would it be okay if i think about it for a second?"

elements.text: also dont be afraid to tell them "oh thats a good question! would it be okay if i think about it for a second?"

text: I've found that if you do need a moment and have a tendency to say "um," then trying to switch to "hmm," or a pause with body language to show you're thinking, comes off better

elements.text: I've found that if you do need a moment and have a tendency to say "um," then trying to switch to "hmm," or a pause with body language to show you're thinking, comes off better

text:
<@U066ED0A4DU> I and even more specifically, to piggy back on this question, which I believe was raised in  the context of the conversation around user account creation and management being considered only one feature -- I wanted to more pointedly ask if that could be split between front and backend.

It seems to me that it has a similar level of both front and backend involvement that the CRUD feature has in terms of implementation and you confirmed CRUD could be split into two features accordingly.

Perhaps you already captured this as a question but wanted to make sure to get it in before you get back to us!
